Stem: Which diagram shows complete metamorphosis?
Image/Diagram Description: Four diagrams (A-D) showing different life cycle types.
Choices: A) [Diagram A], B) [Diagram B], C) [Diagram C], D) [Diagram D]
Scenario Justification: Visual identification of complete metamorphosis from diagrams.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Visual recognition of memorized life cycle type.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to identify complete metamorphosis from visual representations.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data about stage durations for unfamiliar organisms and ask students to classify the life cycle type.

Stem: How are the life cycles of a pumpkin plant and a maple tree similar?
Choices: A) Both plants make seeds only one time in their whole life, B) Both plants start as seeds grow into adult plants and later make seeds again, C) Both plants skip the seedling stage and grow straight into adult plants, D) Both plants can reproduce only when humans plant new parts
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Recall of shared plant life cycle features.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of common plant life cycle patterns.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide growth data for multiple plants and ask students to compare patterns with evidence.

Stem: An adult animal is shown. Which picture BEST shows the offspring of this animal?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of an adult animal plus four possible offspring images (A-D).
Choices: A) [Image A], B) [Image B], C) [Image C], D) [Image D]
Scenario Justification: Visual matching of adult to offspring based on shared features.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — comparing visual features between adult and offspring options.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that offspring resemble their parents.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide trait measurement data for parent and offspring and ask students to identify patterns.

Stem: Parrots get some things from their parents and some from their owners. Which can a parrot get from its owner?
Choices: A) learning to make word-like sounds, B) having a strong beak, C) being able to fly long distances, D) having colorful feathers
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple distinction between inherited and acquired traits.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to distinguish inherited from learned traits.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on parrot traits and their origins for evidence-based reasoning.

Stem: A mob of meerkats live together in a group to increase an individual's ____.
Choices: A) chance of survival, B) body temperature, C) ability to climb trees, D) visibility to other meerkat mobs
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Fill-in-the-blank recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of group behavior benefit.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide survival data for solitary vs group meerkats and ask students to analyze.

Stem: A fossil is shown. Which animal living today is most like the fossil?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of a fossil plus four modern animal images (A-D).
Choices: A) [Animal A], B) [Animal B], C) [Animal C], D) [Animal D]
Scenario Justification: Visual comparison of fossil to modern organisms.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — comparing structural features between fossil and modern organisms.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to identify similarities between extinct and living organisms from visual evidence.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (structural similarities between fossil and modern organisms).
Key Recommendation: Good visual comparison. Add structural feature data for quantitative comparison.

Stem: The fur of sea otters is very thick. How does this help sea otters survive?
Choices: A) The fur helps them breathe, B) The fur keeps them warm, C) The fur protects them from hunters, D) The fur allows them to see underwater
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple identification of adaptation function.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of insulation adaptation.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide temperature data for otters with/without thick fur in different environments.

Stem: An ecosystem described has: land covered with water most of the year, nutrient-rich soil, and other water ecosystems nearby. Which BEST describes this ecosystem?
Choices: A) A tundra, B) A wetland, C) A tropical rainforest, D) A temperate deciduous forest
Scenario Justification: Multi-clue description. Students match characteristics to ecosystem type.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Classification/matching.
DCI Justification: Tests ecosystem identification from characteristics. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (characteristic patterns define ecosystems).
Key Recommendation: Provide actual ecosystem data and ask students to classify from evidence.

Stem: The table shows average temperatures recorded in an area. Which month recorded the highest temperature?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table with monthly average temperatures (Jan-Dec).
Choices: A) March, B) April, C) August, D) October
Scenario Justification: Simple data table reading. Students find the maximum value.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Data lookup.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to read a data table and find maximum.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (identifying the month with highest temperature).
Key Recommendation: Ask students to identify seasonal patterns or predict future temperatures from the data.

Stem: Using data from the bar graph complete the data table to show rainfall measured in each city.
Image/Diagram Description: Bar graph showing rainfall in four Texas cities.
Choices: Dallas: 15 inches; Houston: 20 inches; Austin: 10 inches; San Antonio: 15 inches
Scenario Justification: Data transfer task from bar graph to data table.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — reading values from a bar graph and transferring to a table.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to accurately read a bar graph. Basic data skills.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Ask students to analyze patterns in the data and make predictions rather than just transferring values.

Stem: The table shows typical weather measurements for Pine Valley during four months. Which statement is supported by the data?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table with temperature and precipitation data for Pine Valley across four months.
Choices: A) The month with the least rainfall is January, B) The warmest daytime temperatures occur in July, C) October has more snowfall than January, D) April has the lowest nighttime temperature
Scenario Justification: Real weather data for Pine Valley. Students evaluate multiple claims against data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — checking each statement against the data table to find the one supported by evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires analyzing multi-variable weather data across months.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (identifying correct patterns from data).
Key Recommendation: Strong data analysis question. Students evaluate four claims against a complex dataset.

Stem: A school library near a creek needs a flood barrier. Which solution BEST meets requirements: 30-inch protection, under 45 min install, door accessible, under $8000?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing four solutions with protection level, install time, door access, and cost.
Choices: A) Solution A (40in/60min/Yes/$9200), B) Solution B (25in/30min/Yes/$6500), C) Solution C (32in/40min/No/$5900), D) Solution D (35in/35min/Yes/$7800)
Scenario Justification: Rich engineering design scenario with four specific criteria and constraint data for four solutions.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating multiple solutions against multiple criteria with explicit trade-offs. Students must check each solution against all four requirements.
DCI Justification: Requires multi-variable engineering design evaluation. Deep reasoning about constraints.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (design features → meeting criteria) and Patterns (systematic elimination).
Key Recommendation: Excellent engineering design question. Students systematically evaluate solutions against four criteria.

Stem: Which of these is caused by the gravity of Earth?
Choices: A) water freezing, B) water evaporating, C) water falling to the ground, D) water vapor forming into cloud
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple identification of gravity's effect.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of gravity causing objects to fall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on falling objects and ask students to identify the pattern and explain the cause.

Stem: Two dogs play with a toy. Coco pulls toward herself Rusty pulls away from Coco. As Rusty pulls what is the direction of the opposing force?
Choices: A) toward Coco, B) away from Coco, C) upward, D) downward
Scenario Justification: Scenario about opposing forces with two dogs playing.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — identifying the opposing force direction requires reasoning about Newton's third law.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of opposing forces. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (opposing pulls → opposing force directions).
Key Recommendation: Provide force magnitude data and ask students to predict whether the toy moves and in which direction.

Stem: Someone pushes two shopping carts with the same push. Cart A is empty Cart B is full. Which statement correctly describes what will happen?
Choices: A) Cart A will move farther because an empty cart is easier to speed up, B) Cart B will move farther because heavier objects always move faster, C) Both carts will move the same distance because the push is the same, D) Cart A will move less because lighter objects are harder to move
Scenario Justification: Comparative scenario with mass difference and same force.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about how mass affects motion when force is constant.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of force-mass-motion relationship.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (same force + less mass → more acceleration → greater distance).
Key Recommendation: Provide experimental data showing force-mass-distance relationships.

Stem: A student opens a box with foam pieces. The pieces stick to the student's shirt. What is the most likely reason?
Choices: A) force of gravity, B) magnetic attraction, C) opposite static charges, D) texture of the student's shirt
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about static electricity observation.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — identifying the force responsible for the observed phenomenon.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of static electricity and charge interactions.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (opposite charges → attraction → pieces stick).
Key Recommendation: Provide data from static charge experiments and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: A class builds a game where a token moves through a cardboard maze without touching it using a magnet under the maze. What object can be used as a token?
Choices: A) plastic bead, B) wooden cube, C) metal paper clip, D) rubber eraser
Scenario Justification: Practical problem-solving about magnetic material selection.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Material selection based on magnetic properties.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that only metal objects respond to magnets.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from testing different materials and ask students to explain the pattern.

Stem: Two magnets are too far apart to affect each other. What will most likely happen if Magnet 1 is moved slowly toward Magnet 2?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing two bar magnets with N-S pole orientation visible.
Choices: A) The magnets will attract each other, B) The magnets will repel each other, C) Both magnets will spin around in circles, D) Both magnets will turn on their sides
Scenario Justification: Simple magnet diagram. Students predict interaction based on pole orientation.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Applying known rule about opposite poles.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic attraction between opposite poles.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (opposite poles → attraction).
Key Recommendation: Provide data from experiments at different distances and pole orientations.

Stem: Tommy rubs a balloon in his hair and places it near running water. The water stream moves toward the balloon. Which BEST describes why?
Choices: A) balloon has no charge and water has positive charges, B) balloon is negatively charged and water contains positive charges, C) balloon is positively charged and water has no charge, D) balloon is negatively charged and water has negative charges
Scenario Justification: Scenario about static electricity and water stream deflection.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — explaining the observed phenomenon using charge concepts.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of static charge interactions between objects.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (negative charge on balloon + positive charges in water → attraction → water bends).
Key Recommendation: Good observation-based question. Add data from multiple charged-object experiments.

Stem: A homeowner near a river needs quick flood protection and doesn't mind spending money. Sandbags vs door flood barrier panel. Which BEST addresses the need?
Image/Diagram Description: Description of two flood protection options with cost speed and effectiveness data.
Choices: A) Sandbags because cheaper and reusable, B) Door flood barrier panel because quickly deployed and blocks water better, C) Sandbags because they always stop all water, D) Door flood barrier panel because least expensive
Scenario Justification: Engineering design scenario with specific criteria and two options to evaluate.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating solutions against stated criteria (speed and effectiveness matter more than cost).
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of engineering design trade-offs.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (design features → meeting specific criteria).
Key Recommendation: Good engineering context. Add quantitative data about deployment time and water blockage rates.

Stem: Which sequence shows the order of stages in a plant's life cycle?
Choices: A) young plant → seed → adult plant, B) seed → adult plant → young plant, C) adult plant → young plant → seed, D) seed → young plant → adult plant
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure sequence recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Ordering memorized sequence.
DCI Justification: Tests life cycle stage knowledge. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide growth data for a plant and ask students to identify stages from evidence.

Stem: Which statement correctly describes the relationship between parts of a tomato plant?
Choices: A) Stem produces fruits directly which later develop flowers, B) Fruits form first then flowers develop, C) Stems produce flowers and fruits simultaneously, D) Flowers form then develop into fruits which contain seeds that can grow into new plants
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Recall of plant structure relationships.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of flower-fruit-seed sequence.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide plant structure observation data and ask students to identify the sequence from evidence.

Stem: A class studies ear shape in rabbits. They record pointed vs rounded ears. Which claim is BEST supported by the data?
Image/Diagram Description: Data display showing parent ear shapes and offspring ear shapes across multiple rabbit families.
Choices: A) Ear shape is inherited from parents and offspring can show variation between parents' different traits, B) Ear shape is chosen by what the rabbits eat, C) All babies always have same ear shape as the mother, D) Rabbits will have a new ear shape that neither parent has
Scenario Justification: Data-based investigation of rabbit ear shape inheritance with class data display.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — selecting the claim best supported by the class data.
DCI Justification: Requires analyzing inheritance data to determine that ear shape is inherited but shows variation.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (offspring ear shapes relate to parent ear shapes with variation).
Key Recommendation: Excellent data-based inheritance question with real class data display.

Stem: What causes objects thrown into the air to come down again?
Choices: A) the force of friction, B) the force of gravity, C) the temperature of the environment, D) the time of day
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Basic recall of gravity concept.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of gravity.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on falling objects at different heights and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Buffalo travel in large herds. When a predator chases one buffalo the herd runs together making it harder to catch one. Which is the BEST argument for how herds help survival?
Choices: A) Being in a herd makes every buffalo faster, B) Buffalo only live in herds to find water, C) Living in a herd keeps buffalo from ever getting sick, D) Being in a herd makes it harder for a predator to target one animal so more can escape
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about buffalo herd behavior with specific predator-prey dynamics described.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — evaluating which argument best explains the survival advantage.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of group behavior and predator dilution effect.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (herd → difficulty targeting → more escape).
Key Recommendation: Good argument evaluation. Provide data comparing predation success rates for herds vs individuals.

Stem: A duck has webbed feet. This body structure helps the duck survive by making it easier to ____.
Choices: A) breathe underwater, B) scare away predators with loud sounds, C) swim through water, D) stay warm by trapping air in feathers
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple identification of webbed feet function.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of structural adaptation.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data comparing swimming speed of webbed vs non-webbed birds.

Stem: Prairie dogs make a loud barking sound when they see a hawk overhead. Other prairie dogs quickly run into burrows. This behavior is an example of ____.
Choices: A) hibernating, B) communicating, C) reproducing, D) migrating
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario describing prairie dog alarm behavior.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Simple classification of behavior type.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of communication as a group survival behavior.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on prairie dog colony survival with and without alarm calls.

Stem: A student says 'In Lakeview the warmest season is also the wettest season.' Which statement BEST evaluates the student's claim using the data?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table with average highest temperatures and rainfall amounts for Lakeview across seasons.
Choices: A) The claim is correct because summer has the highest temperature and the most rain, B) The claim is incorrect because summer is the warmest but spring has the most rain, C) The claim is correct because spring and summer both have higher temperatures than winter, D) The claim is incorrect because winter has the lowest temperature and the most rain
Scenario Justification: Real weather data with a student claim to evaluate. Students must check the claim against data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — evaluating a student's claim by examining data for both temperature and precipitation.
DCI Justification: Requires analyzing two variables (temperature and precipitation) across seasons to evaluate a claim.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (seasonal patterns in temperature vs precipitation are different).
Key Recommendation: Excellent claim evaluation question. Students must analyze data to determine if the claim is supported.

Stem: A fossil skull is shown. Which information can be learned by examining this fossil?
Choices: A) the habitat where the animal lived, B) the temperatures the animal preferred, C) the size of the population where the animal lived, D) the type of food the animal ate
Scenario Justification: Visual observation of fossil skull. Students determine what can be inferred.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about what information a fossil skull can provide.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that skull/tooth structure indicates diet but not habitat or population size.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (skull/tooth shape → diet information).
Key Recommendation: Good concept. Add comparison data between multiple fossil skulls and modern animal skulls.

Stem: Horse nettle plants have spines. Caterpillars eat the leaves. Kim removes all spines from one plant half from another and leaves all on a third. She measures time for caterpillar to eat all leaves. Select words to complete a claim supported by Kim's investigation.
Image/Diagram Description: Bar graph showing results of Kim's investigation: time for caterpillar to eat leaves varies by spine amount.
Choices: Spines [increase] the survival of horse nettle plants because caterpillars eat leaves very slowly on horse nettle plants with [many] spines.
Scenario Justification: Rich experimental investigation with controlled variables and bar graph data. Students must construct a claim from evidence.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — constructing a claim supported by experimental data from the investigation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how a structural feature (spines) functions as a defense and interpreting experimental evidence.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (more spines → slower eating → better plant survival) and Structure and Function.
Key Recommendation: Excellent experimental evidence question. Students construct a claim from investigation data.

Stem: Which evidence BEST supports the claim in Question 30?
Choices: A) Plants without spines survive the best because caterpillars eat spineless leaves very quickly, B) Plants with only a few spines survive best because caterpillars prefer leaves with many spines, C) Plants survive with and without spines because caterpillars eat all leaves in the same time, D) Plants with many spines survive best because caterpillars eat fewer leaves in a day on plants with more spines
Scenario Justification: Follow-up evidence evaluation using the same horse nettle investigation data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — selecting the evidence statement that best supports the claim from Q30.
DCI Justification: Requires evaluating multiple evidence statements against the investigation results.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (many spines → caterpillars eat less → better survival).
Key Recommendation: Strong companion to Q30. Together they form an excellent claim-evidence assessment pair.

Stem: After a big storm soil washes into a pond making water muddy. This makes it harder for animals to find food and plants to get sunlight. Which solution is MOST LIKELY to help?
Choices: A) Plant grasses and reeds along the pond edge to hold soil in place, B) Pour more soil into the pond to make it deeper, C) Remove the plants around the pond so water can flow faster, D) Add soap to the pond to make water look clearer
Scenario Justification: Environmental problem scenario with cause-effect chain described. Students evaluate solutions.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating which solution addresses the root cause of the problem.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the erosion problem and identifying a solution that prevents soil runoff.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (storm → erosion → muddy water → problems; plants → hold soil → prevent erosion).
Key Recommendation: Good environmental engineering question. Add data on soil erosion with/without vegetation.

Stem: Santiago Chile is in the Southern Hemisphere. Summers are Dec-Feb winters are Jun-Aug. Which statement BEST describes the climate?
Image/Diagram Description: Climate data graphs/charts for Santiago Chile.
Choices: A) Temperature and precipitation do not change throughout the year, B) The summer months have higher temperatures than winter months, C) There is more precipitation in summer months than winter months, D) Santiago is very hot and dry all year with no rain
Scenario Justification: Real climate data for a Southern Hemisphere city. Students must interpret data considering reversed seasons.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — reading climate data for a Southern Hemisphere city and evaluating statements.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that seasons are reversed in Southern Hemisphere and reading data correctly.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (seasonal temperature patterns in climate data).
Key Recommendation: Strong data analysis question with Southern Hemisphere context adding complexity.

Stem: Jane builds a race car track. The car rolls down the ramp onto flat track but stops before the finish line. What should Jane do to her design so the car reaches the finish line?
Image/Diagram Description: Four diagrams showing different track modifications (higher ramp, shorter flat, steeper ramp, etc.).
Choices: A) [Design A], B) [Design B], C) [Design C], D) [Design D]
Scenario Justification: Engineering design iteration scenario. Students must select the improvement that addresses the problem.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating design modifications to solve a specific problem (car doesn't reach finish line).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that increasing the ramp height/steepness gives more speed to travel farther.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (higher ramp → more speed → car reaches finish line).
Key Recommendation: Strong engineering design iteration question. Students analyze and improve a design based on test results.
